title: 104_hr1122
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alaska Power Administration Sale Act" and includes definitions for clarity. The Act, known as the "Alaska Power Administration Sale Act," defines key terms such as "Eklutna assets," "Eklutna Purchase Agreement," "Eklutna Purchasers," and "Memorandum of Agreement." These terms relate to the Eklutna Hydroelectric Project and its related assets, involving various entities including the Municipality of Anchorage, Chugach Electric Association, and Matanuska Electric Association. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy, while "Snettishan assets" pertain to the Snettisham Hydroelectric Project and related assets as outlined in the Snettisham Purchase Agreement of February 10, 1989. SEC. 3. SALE OF SNETTISHAM AND EKLUTNA ASSETS. The Secretary is authorized to sell and transfer the Snettisham assets to Alaska and the Eklutna assets to the Eklutna Purchasers. Other US agencies must cooperate in the sales. Appropriations are authorized for preparing and acquiring assets for sale. SEC. 4. EXEMPTION. The Eklutna and Snettisham hydroelectric projects will remain exempt from the Federal Power Act after authorized sales. The exemption does not impact the Memorandum of Agreement. SEC. 5. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The United States District Court for the District of Alaska has jurisdiction to review decisions under the Memorandum of Agreement, including specific performance. Actions challenging the Fish and Wildlife Program must be brought within 90 days of adoption. Review of program implementation must be done within 90 days of the challenged act. Rights-of-Way and other lands for the Eklutna Project are specified in the Eklutna Purchase Agreement. The Secretary of the Interior will issue rights-of-way to the Alaska Power Administration for the Eklutna Purchasers at no cost. These rights-of-way will be effective for the life of the Eklutna hydroelectric project and will allow for operation, maintenance, and access to project facilities on military and Bureau of Land Management lands. If the Eklutna Purchasers sell or transfer, the rights-of-way will remain in place. If the Eklutna Purchasers sell the hydroelectric project, the Bureau of Land Management can charge fees for rights-of-way use. The Secretary will transfer land to the Purchasers at no cost if claims are invalid. The State of Alaska can select Eklutna lands for conveyance. The Secretary of the Interior will convey improved lands to the State of Alaska under selection entitlements from specific agreements. The State may select and receive approximately 2,671 acres of Snettisham lands. The expiration of the State's selection rights under a specific Act is noted. The State of Alaska has the right to select lands under the Alaska Statehood Act and must complete selections within one year. The Secretary of the Interior will convey selected lands to the State, with limitations on total acreage transfer. The Act of July 7, 1958 allows for the transfer of acreage to the State of Alaska. The Act of August 9, 1955 regarding water resources investigations in Alaska is repealed. Asset sales under this Act are not considered disposal of Federal surplus property. Certain laws will cease to apply once Eklutna assets are conveyed to Eklutna Purchasers. The Act of July 7, 1958 allows for the transfer of acreage to the State of Alaska, with certain laws ceasing to apply once all Snettisham assets are conveyed to the State. SEC. 6. TERMINATION OF ALASKA POWER ADMINISTRATION. The Alaska Power Administration will be terminated within one year after the authorized sales, with unobligated funds returned to the Treasury. Amendments to the DOE Organization Act include removing a subparagraph and redesignating others. The amendments authorize the Secretary of Energy to sell the Snettisham and Eklutna hydroelectric projects administered by the Alaska Power Administration. The Alaska Power Administration will be terminated within one year after the sales, with unobligated funds returned to the Treasury. Amendments to the DOE Organization Act include removing a subparagraph and redesignating others.
